title: Octopus Renewables Infrastructure Trust's (LON:ORIT) Dividend Will Be £0.0154
description: Octopus Renewables Infrastructure Trust plc's ( LON:ORIT ) investors are due to receive a payment of £0.0154 per share...
content:
Octopus Renewables Infrastructure Trust plc's (LON:ORIT) investors are due to receive a payment of £0.0154 per share on 29th of August. This makes the dividend yield 8.6%, which will augment investor returns quite nicely.

Trump has pledged to "unleash" American oil and gas and these 15 US stocks have developments that are poised to benefit.

Octopus Renewables Infrastructure Trust's Projections Indicate Future Payments May Be Unsustainable

Impressive dividend yields are good, but this doesn't matter much if the payments can't be sustained. Prior to this announcement, the company was paying out 288% of what it was earning and 75% of cash flows. While the cash payout ratio isn't necessarily a cause for concern, the company is probably focusing more on returning cash to shareholders than growing the business.

Looking forward, EPS could fall by 0.2% if the company can't turn things around from the last few years. If the dividend continues along recent trends, we estimate the payout ratio could reach 315%, which could put the dividend in jeopardy if the company's earnings don't improve.

See our latest analysis for Octopus Renewables Infrastructure Trust

Even though the company has been paying a consistent dividend for a while, we would like to see a few more years before we feel comfortable relying on it. Since 2020, the dividend has gone from £0.0424 total annually to £0.0602. This implies that the company grew its distributions at a yearly rate of about 7.3% over that duration. The dividend has been growing as a reasonable rate, which we like. However, investors will probably want to see a longer track record before they consider Octopus Renewables Infrastructure Trust to be a consistent dividend paying stock.

The company's investors will be pleased to have been receiving dividend income for some time. Unfortunately things aren't as good as they seem. Although it's important to note that Octopus Renewables Infrastructure Trust's earnings per share has basically not grown from where it was five years ago, which could erode the purchasing power of the dividend over time.

The Dividend Could Prove To Be Unreliable

Overall, it's nice to see a consistent dividend payment, but we think that longer term, the current level of payment might be unsustainable. The payments are bit high to be considered sustainable, and the track record isn't the best. We would probably look elsewhere for an income investment.
summary: Octopus Renewables Infrastructure Trust plc's (LON:ORIT) investors are set to receive a dividend payment of £0.0154 per share on 29th August, making the dividend yield 8.6%. However, future payments may not be sustained due to projections that the company's payout ratio could reach 315%, potentially jeopardising the dividend if it continues to grow. The company's earnings per share has not grown from where it was five years ago, which could erode the purchasing power of the dividend over time. Since 2020, the dividend has grown at a yearly rate of about 7.3% over that period. However, investors may expect a longer track record before considering Octopus Renewable Infrastructure Trust as a consistent dividend paying stock.

argos_summary: Octopus Renewables Infrastructure Trust plc (ORIT) is set to pay a dividend of £0.0154 per share on August 29, yielding 8.6%. However, concerns arise as the company has been paying out significantly more than its earnings, with a payout ratio projected to reach 315%, potentially jeopardizing future dividends. Despite a consistent dividend history and a growth rate of about 7.3% since 2020, the lack of earnings growth over the past five years raises doubts about the sustainability of these payments.
